column1: In the great square the boldest among the boys often tied their sledges to the country people's carts
column2: and thus rode with them a good way. They went capitally. When they were in the midst of their playing there came a great sledge. It was painted quite white
column3: and in it sat somebody wrapped in a rough
column6: rough cap on his head. The sledge drove twice round the square
column7: and Kay bound his little sledge to it
column8: and so he drove on with it. It went faster and faster
column9: straight into the next street. The man who drove turned round and nodded in a familiar way to Kay; it was as if they knew one another. Each time when Kay wanted to cast loose his little sledge
column11: and then Kay remained where he was
column12: and thus they drove out at the town gate.
